ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Amazing course, lower workload but tangible, small steps each week. There are 2-3 online quizzes each week where you can learn new material in an interactive way, and it doesn't feel mentally draining at all, however it is very fascinating if you are mildly interested in music. The knowledge and skills you acquire makes you feel understand music much easier. My main goal was to have a sense of music for the future, and I totally got this from the course. I will almost definitely continue with other music courses at Yale, especially 218 and 207, although I am not even close to being a music major.
Learned a lot about the origins of music scales.
I learned a lot about the basics of music theory

I used to play piano when I was younger but never learned music theory, so I always struggled to understand how to sight read or improvise or what a key signature meant. This class completely changed how I understand music, and I feel like I can return to playing music with new eyes.
Basics of music theory.
Indian music culture. Basics of rhythm and staff notation.
I learned the basics of music theory and how to apply this theory to the music that I hear everyday.
I learned about basic notation and how to read music.
I gained a valuable knowledge on the history of music.
Ability to read music, listen to patterns in music, all things notes related.
Learned the circle of fifths and the basics of chords and song making
This course completely changed the way I approach different kinds of music.

I learned the basics of exploring musical realms through South Indian music theory and scales, and developed the ability to relate pitches and rhythms to each other to better understand the different ways that music can be constructed.
Awesome class
I learned how to read musical notes and keys and will definitely use these skills in the future. I learned about music tones such as seconds, thirds, fourths, fifths, etc as well.

I learned what different kinds of scales were (chromatic, diatonic, etc.), got better at sight-reading  both letter names of notes and solfege and recognizing key signatures, and learned a lot about triads!
Basic music theory knowledge
I learned about how to read music, key signatures, time signatures, how harmonies work and different introductory musical theory concepts.

A real appreciation for the components that go into making a musical song, the rudiments of harmonic and diatonic analysis, a love for music theory altogether - definitely a gateway drug of a class that has already changed the trajectory of my academic life

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The Professor and TAs are truly exceptional. Workload is very managable. Interesting topics that you would have never learned otherwise.
Sometimes it was a little fast paced and hard to follow, but overall it was very engaging and fun!
Sometimes the terminology builds up fast for someone who isnt very familiar with any music theory, but overall, I think the in class singing activities make learning the content much more manageable.
Teach the topic what is asked in homework in a more concrete way during class.

I believe that the "robo-quizzes" were very helpful in getting familiar with musical notation. The one thing I would hope for in the future is more of an emphasis on reading staff notation later in the course.
I think this class should be split based on musical background and knowledge. Sometimes it could seem too easy or too hard, not consistently manageable.
I thought the course was great overall.
Great course. Light workload, engaging teacher.
I think 1 on 1 tutoring or smaller group sessions would improve this class since when we all sing as a group it's harder to tell if someone's off pitch.
I really enjoyed the format of the course. The robo-quizzes helped supplement Professor Quinn's exceptional teaching extremely well.

This course does not cover the basics of music theory as described. The material is extremely interesting and should definitely continue being taught, but in coordination with a more structured foundational teaching.
Awesome class

The strengths of the class are how the assignments help us understand the lessons we are learning and how we sing in class to help us know the pitch and tones. There were no weaknesses in this course.
Strengths: Professor Quinn is very encouraging! He meets you where you are and creates a welcoming space for confusion. Weaknesses: The class lasts 75 minutes, which can feel long.
Not much engagement

I appreciated all the participatory exercises we did in class. I sing acapella and found myself applying the different concepts we learned in class when learning new arrangements for my group. I found myself forgetting the official names of some of the things we were learning sometimes it mightve helpful to have a compiled notes document of some sort on top of the robo quiz instructions.

Everyone (from day one) knew that this course was being workshopped and developed as it was being taught, and so the feeling of having a bunch of disjointed components that only tenuously fit together was fairly pervasive (and acknowledged by Prof. Quinn as well.) Even so, the course was fantastic. Prof. Quinn is the consummate theory teacher. He cares so much about both music and his students, devotes so much effort to creating beautiful graphics and visuals to aid memorization and analysis, and overall is just a wonderful pedagogue who made every class an event to look forward to. As someone who dabbled in theory beforehand and never really "got it", Prof. Quinn's usage of the line of fifths (and insistence on focusing on chroma, sharpness [ti] and flatness [fa] in the scale itself) was truly unique and an incredibly effective way to learn theory. One strong suggestion I would have is to split the course into two tracks, sort of what exists in the Physics department (and what DSAC is trying to implement in the Computer Science dep't), namely - just because students come into the track with no background at all doesn't mean that some of them (e.g. myself) don't want to cover a ton of ground and get a lot of practice, far more than is generally associated with MUSI 110 (known as a "gut"). Making an intensive introduction to music theory track in parallel would be something I'd love to see and that I would have loved to have taken myself. In terms of the actual course materials themselves, I think Prof. Quinn is quite aware of what could be better, what needs to be scrapped, etc. (but just in case / some other thoughts: we never did anything with the melakartas after the two days we spent on them; I would have liked to see more discussion of functional analysis and a bit more roman numeral analysis, since it was mentioned altogether; it would be cool to introduce some maqamat [albeit very complicated with the course as is]; homework was nonexistent for the second half of the course and was sorely missed; the musical capabilities of the group were such that we probably could have used Sibelius/Noteflight/Musescore for the last assignment, which would have given us experience with an important set of tools for writing music; a lecture/section model would make good use of the TAs and would have been very helpful for me)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Outstanding course. The most engaging and fun classes I have taken at yale.
Absolutely! Totally amazing!
Yes. Very interesting especially if you want to get outside of your comfort zone.
Yes! Whether you know anything about music or not, this is very helpful
I would recommend this to anyone with an interest in any music. The course really builds up foundational understand and not just for one specific type of music or instrument.
Yes I would recommend this course because learning music is fun.
If this student is interested in music, I would recommend this course.
I would if theyre interested in the music major.
Absolutely.
100% recommend if you want to learn some basic Indian music.
Yes, great intro to music for those with no music background. It's super fun, you learn by singing.
Yes.

Yes, because although engagement levels outside of class were often low, the material we covered and explored academically and even physically in class present an innovative form of learning a new subject.
Awesome class
Yes. I would recommend this course to other students especially if you are interested in music. This course has excellent engagement and allows you to understand the fundamentals of music.

Yes! If you know a little bit about music theory and want to know more (for example, I took piano lessons as a kid so I could read music but I didn't really understand chords or harmony) then this is the perfect class for you!
Yes, if they want to learn music theory
Yes! Definitely it was very fun!
Yes, it helped me officially learn concepts I was familiar with but hadnt learned in a formal setting before.

Take this class! It is the gateway drug to all other music theory classes; you will never hear music the same way. This class gives you a solid foundation in scales, intervals, key signatures, rudiments of chords and harmony, Carnatic music, time signatures and beat, and in general is super important for anyone looking to be musically literate.
